name: Kepler-55
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-55 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-55 is a star with 0.5199999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.62 times its radius. It is located 1919.33 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-55 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-55 d

Kepler-55 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.21 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-55.

The mass of Kepler-55 d is 2.94 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-55 d is 1.59 that of Earth. At 2.94 Earth masses, Kepler-55 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-55 e

Kepler-55 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.62 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-55.

The mass of Kepler-55 e is 2.74 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-55 e is 1.55 that of Earth. At 2.74 Earth masses, Kepler-55 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-55 f

Kepler-55 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.20 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-55.

The mass of Kepler-55 f is 2.94 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-55 f is 1.59 that of Earth. At 2.94 Earth masses, Kepler-55 f is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-55, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
